review_title: Toxic Racist Leadership @ The Developing Brain Institute
pros: Childrens is a prestigious and reputable hospital. Proximity to the name and brand definitely allows increased access to resources. Pay is competitive for some (see below). The work itself is interesting and meaningful.
cons:
Childrens allows unchecked anti-Black racism and toxic leadership to persist from the highest level within The Developing Brain Institute because the founding director is excellent at winning grants and considered a leader in our field. Nepotism is also a factor.

- there is a persistent and sizable (>10k) wage gap between white employees and their Black counterparts in similar/the same roles
- Black women are regularly and openly scolded for “tone”, “aggression”, dress code, and time and attendance in ways that white employees and even other employees of color are absolutely not. It is clear that their is a higher level of scrutiny, even on the quality of research, when Black employees present during journal clubs and research review meetings

Other workplace norms that I would (less directly) contribute to a culture of white supremacy and surveillance in the workplace 
- no WFH allowed under any circumstances even for non-patient facing, research oriented, “cubicle” type jobs
- significant turnover in all roles, but most notable with Black staff, who have comprised the greater majority of the resignations within the last year despite being overall under represented on this team
- nasty “reply all” emails when any staff is briefly unaccounted for (ie. In a meeting, in the bathroom) despite the director regularly being in another state or country without informing her team
- passive aggressive and awkward all staff meetings reiterating and reinforcing all of the above workplace norms and behaviors at DBI

review_title: Least transparent and supportive working environment
pros: Hospitals benefits are adequate (vacation, health insurance, dental).
cons: I have been in the medical industry and research field for quite some time now. I was specifically embedded in the Developing Brain Institute with a core mission to expand scientific research and work collaboratively in a lab that was presented to me on Interview day; however, this was not at all the experience I had during my time there. Those in leadership are not skilled in managing a team of faculty members, fellows, coordinators, or students. There lacks transparency, communication, accountability, and scholarly collaboration. Team members are preferred to be siloed and interactions with leadership are minimal (1 time per 3 months if that) and they are not genuine during the limited time you get. Emails are not answered in a timely manner or at all and if so leadership plans to “circle back” but never do. Priority is “data” but nothing else. Within my time there over 20 people had been fired without notice (escorted after to the lobby) or resigned due to toxic working environments. This has been the highest turn over lab I have ever been a part of. Also no working from home options- not even 3 months after the start of the pandemic. If I learned anything it’s that you are only as scholarly and grand as the quality and ethics of your leadership. Unfortunately this experience set me back a couple years.

review_title: An excellent NICU to be a part of
pros:
The shift differentials are the best I’ve seen across multiple facilities (it’s percentage based, not a flat rate). 
Their incentive bonuses to pick up overtime can be very generous—you do not HAVE to pick up OT, you won’t get personal calls or texts, but if you want it, it’s usually there.
 The physician/nurse relationship (at least in NICU) is very good. 
This is a union facility —I consider that a plus. Regular raises are in the contract.
Self scheduling is fairly accommodating and I often get what I request. 
Residency for new grads and new-to-specialty is the most comprehensive that I’ve seen. It’s tough, for sure, and possible to fail out of, but the caliber of NICU nurses that graduate is phenomenal.
Children’s swag!
cons:
Floating. NICU floats to PICU and CICU (and vice versa).
Cerner charting system. 
If you work days, you have to park at an off campus garage.
If you want to work strictly days, it’s going to be about three years before you have enough seniority. Until then, you’re going to have to rotate days and nights. However, if you’re experienced and want straight nights, you can absolutely do that.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: I enjoyed working with my coworkers and I felt supported by my boss. The patients and families were our focus, and that made it easy to find ways we can improve the care we provide for them rather than on mistakes or difficulties in our work. They made the work fun in a lot of ways while maintaining integrity and a strong work ethic. Working with children keeps you on your toes and you'll always have a funny story to get you through the day because kids say the darndest things. The staff clearly care about the patients and the families and it feels good to see how they're supported by everyone.
cons: The doctors do not care about the staff working to support their research and have strong, personal relationships with HR, so you will have a hard time getting support from them. If your job is grant funded, you will not receive severance if you're let go and they can give you as much or as little notice as they want, so you're at their whim. Starting in summer 2021, you will not receive a payout for your vacation time when you leave because they're trying to compensate for their "losses" during the pandemic, even though they forced every single employee to take a week of vacation time or unpaid leave to save money. There is limited upward mobility in research, and Aetna is arguably the worst insurance company in the DMV so you don't get enough benefits for the cost.

review_title: Care is Good and the Physicians are Dedicated but Senior Leadership is Bad!
pros: Staff are very dedicated and provide good care to children.  The pay and benefits are very good but not worth the treatment you receive.  There's a reason Children's has to pay more.
cons: Senior leadership is horrible to work for!  The culture is abusive.  Senior Leaders are mean spirited and don't get along with each other and pull others into their disagreements.  Senior leaders are not supportive of those that report to them.  Human Resources lacks "human".  Orientation for new managers is non-existent and new managers struggle and then are chastised when they don't know what to do or how to get things done.  If "Children's" was not in the name of the employer, I would not know I worked for an organization that cared for children.  There are double standards for the behavior of certain leaders in the organization.  This was the worst environment I have ever worked in.  How come an employee satisfaction or engagement survey is not conducted?  The Senior Leadership would rather not know because a few of them might not be working there any longer if certain behaviors were exposed.  My previous experience wasn't valued because it wasn't "The Children's way".  Children's does not work to retain employees.  There is high turnover and Senior Leaders do not care.  It's all about the bottom line.

review_title: Mob bullying is overlooked..seems to be encouraged since, if you ask for help, union & HR turn against the bullied.
pros: The children. There's very little else that makes working here worth the toll it takes on your health. I'm looking for other employment.
cons: Poor, & expensive parking. Disabled parking isn't monitored well. Benefits are expensive. High turnover in management (so they rely on the rumors from bullies, aimed @ character defamation). Poor management of employees...thus, if you have high work ethic, expect that you'll get stuck with the bulk of work while others socialize, not to mention that you'll become a target. Where else are you required, against your will, to pay union dues? Don't expect help from HR, the union, or management when you're bullied...they'll just make you the problem & allow negative lies to be added to your annual review. (They've got plenty of security to keep you in check...) Shocked to learn that hospitals rate alongside USPS bully tactics.

job_title: Registered Nurse II in Washington, DC
pros: Working with children, awesome health care providers, great professional relationships
cons: The definition of bureaucracy. Since CNHS re-brands everything with a 'bear" theme, they should call it bear-acracy. Management has serious issues at this institution. "Leadership" (always sure to use the capital "L" when addressing the plebs)  is a club. There is no accountability for any actions. Medicare fraud? No one is held accountable, Instead, Leadership throws a positive "spin" on the event. An IT disaster? 18000 hacked patient accounts? No information provided to employees, and no one is held accountable. The IT departments' definition of a paperless system: enter an order in the computer, print it out, and hand deliver it. Constant downtime. Even the outside website was down for more than 48 hours, and internal connectivity affected: phones went down.The EMR is implemented horribly, it's basically bloatware, and is a serious impediment to professional staff accomplishing their work. IT needs to be cleansed, starting at the top, and all the way down. The institution probably spent millions on marketing a "Bear Institute" to no avail. Nothing has developed from it, and things have only gotten worse. Computers are slow, we could hardly hold conferences.  A horrible IT system? No one held accountable. I've worked at numerous other hospitals where IT and the EMR have worked. It CAN be done. Why not here??

Unit Managers are more worried about things like convenience items like toiletries and toys than staffing issues and equipment issues. review_title: An old fashioned, authoritarian prison, and very sneaky too
pros: Helping little babies is the only positive thing I can say about this hospital. The fact that they provide a shuttle service to main metro stations is also another plus; but I cannot think of any other features.
cons:
Workers have no rights; only responsibilities that include watching on each other's shoulder and reporting to the higher ups. However, when you do report to the higher ups, they quickly fire you! In general, everyone seems to be working under pressure and holding some grudge.
Heavy security at the door is very scary; the place does not look like an inviting institute. 
At the entrance, there is the picture of an Arab guy (who has donated money to the hospital) holding a child on his lap. It is very creepy! 
The fact that the hospital racks up 40 million dollars in legal fees per year is telling something about the cultural values of this hospital. 
The administration is very sloppy and incompetent.
The contract are written very vaguely, and they make sure the worker is disadvantaged. I got fired as soon as I raised an issue with the contractual agreement, you are cornered to shut up or put up!

pros: Children's National is truly one of the leading pediatric healthcare institutions in the world and everyday you feel honored to be a part of it and contribute in any way to the incredible work happening there. The CEO is a really wonderful leader who has and continues to transform the place. Children's National pays very well for non profits in DC.
cons: The Children's Hospital Foundation is a very intense place where most folks don't last very long. From the top down the expectations can be unreasonable and as a whole, very reactive, so you are constantly dealing with fire drills and never feel like you're getting ahead. Support staff and middle management are not treated great and don't feel valued so there is a ton of turnover.

review_title: Okay, but it could be better
job_title: Business Operations Associate in Silver Spring, MD
pros:
- Paid time off 
- Working from home (this depends on the job position and department)
- Health, dental, and vision care
- Flexible hours: You can come in to work anytime between 5am to 9am, as long as you work the full 8 hours a day. 
- 1 hour long lunch break
cons:
- Employee morale: I've seen a lot of people talking behind other people's backs. Because of this, it doesn't seem like we all a part of a team. 
- Work environment: Impossible to get work done because others are being distractive. There is also some micromanaging from team leaders. 
- Have to use your paid time off for snow days if you don't usually work from home. 
- Co-workers might slack off and you might get stuck with more work. 
- Not enough training: Sometimes we have to figure out stuff on our own without any help or direction especially with new software updates.

pros: The mission and the tremendous talent at Children's National are compelling reasons for working there.  It is also a place where one is thanked for one's work and one's efforts are appreciated--at least in certain areas.
cons: The downsides are: non-clinical departments spread out within DC, Silver Spring and elsewhere, which impedes successful work and alignment of how goals and objectives will be met; the inadequate parking situation at the hospital itself, which represents a significant barrier to visiting for work-related purposes when one's office is located off-site; and the very hierarchical culture, which means that leadership does not feel obliged to (or even comfortable with) getting to know everyone else.

cons: You're as happy as you want to be here. There are some bad apples that always have negative things to say but if you get away from them, you'll be amazed at the extraordinary and wonderful staff who love their job and the kids and are making huge strides in children's health.

review_title: CNMC is a farce. Focus is public image not employee satisfaction. "Do more with less" should be the motto.
pros: Working alongside experts in the field. Good academic opportunities. Culturally diverse populations and many outlying satellite locations.
cons:
This place is all about marketing. Employee satisfaction is not important. Making money is the bottom line and everyone is unhappy. This institution is poorly managed. Morale is low. Don't think about growing financially here. Your starting salary may entice you but that's where you stay forever unless you are in a union. The APNs have foolishly voted the union out and are now stagnant in pay for most departments. 
Bullying and discrimination by management is not handled properly.
Systems in place are completely disorganized.

review_title: Children's National - Great Heart for Service, issues within organization that need to be addressed
pros: The best reasons to work at Children's National would have to be the kids and families that you serve. Even if you are a member of Environmental Services, it's easier to do your job knowing that a child benefits from clean bathrooms. Likewise, in my field it's beneficial to know that even if you are simply writing a press release, the exposure can help with getting more donors, which in turn, is more money for better technology.
cons: The hierarchical society at work. Also, it's spread out in so many different locations, you have people doing whatever they want, which is a PR person's nightmare!

review_title: The foundation is full of silos and politics
pros: The people are nice and the salaries are good. Foundation offices are metro accessible
cons:
The job can be good if you're committed to coasting or just getting by. A lot of actual progress gets limited by organizational politics, poor management, lack of collaboration, etc. Ambition goes away quickly when you consistently run into barrier after barrier at the smallest levels. 

There is a lot of work that needs to be done to get the organization up to general best practices and organization is resistant to change. No strong leadership to drive strategy or get teams to work together. Priority is highly focused on Major Gifts and other forms of philanthropy is underdeveloped. 

While every organization has a degree of politics and dysfunction, I've never seen a place this bad. Use extreme caution before accepting a job here.

review_title: Stay Away from Patient Access DEPT
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Washington, DC
pros: Children's is an amazing company that provides services for children and families.  The Doctors & Nurses truly know their craft.  The benefits are very affordable and competitive.
cons: However the bad outweighs the good.  The attitude of staff at Children's is unbearable.  Management does nothing to correct unprofessional staff.  They do not appreciate hard working employees. The turn over rate in staff is ridiculous.  The only steady staff are Doctors, and 30 year front desk staff that are miserable and rude.

review_title: Motivating place to make a difference
pros: Excellence opportunity to connect  yourself to something important.  The organization makes a strong daily impact on child health in both clinical and research areas.  The talent of the teams is strong in most areas, and you won't find many workplaces with smarter colleagues.  Executive team has some very strong leaders and is improving with time. cons: Executive team is somewhat large, reflecting the academic nature of the organization.

Has twice the number of employees for similar size institutions. Incredible and ridiculous bureaucracy established by legal/compliance. Yet this is the least clinically compliant hospital ever experienced by numerous individuals who came from other institutions.

review_title: great place to start as a new grad nurse
pros: This is sort of a mix of pros and cons.  I worked as an RN I/II for several years in a variety of positions, including RN on the respiratory care floor, RN on the medical care floor, phone triage RN for outpatient gastroenterology, and RN on the child psych floor.  My first job as a new grad was on the respiratory care floor (which merged with medical care and doesn't exist anymore) and it was a great place to start, learn/practice new skills, get mentoring, etc.  Medical care was crazy and management seemed very much removed from the floor nurses despite being in an office on the unit.  They also seemed to only talk to floor RNs when disciplinary action needed to be taken and never for praise or anything positive.  GI phone triage wasn't too bad, but the attendings were fairly unappreciative of the triage nurses despite how much we helped field all of their patients' calls.  Child psych had great management but was a pretty chaotic environment, although I imagine it's probably the same in any child psych unit at any hospital.
cons:
1. Not feeling appreciated by management/superiors in various departments (medical care; outpatient gastroenterology)
2. Management seemed to be there for punitive reasons only and almost never offered praise for a job well done
3. Many ancillary staff are very unprofessional and sometimes lazy (techs, unit clerks, etc.).  Delegating to most techs on medical care seemed pointless sometimes because the RN ended up doing half of what was delegated due to the tech not doing it and not reporting to the nurse that it hadn't been done until the nurse checked up on the tech later in the shift and found that there were many uncompleted tasks.
4. There are many amazing, hard-working, talented RNs all over the hospital, but of course there are lazy ones too who don't help their peers even when asked for help, always seem to be in the break room when other nursing are busting their butts for 12 hours straight.  I'm sure this exists at every hospital, though.

pros: Opportunity to work at a stand alone hospital strictly for children,bright innovative surgeons,
cons: It is embarrassing at times when I hear the way personnel talk to each other and even more importantly to parents. It is very disturbing. Limited experience of staff. Some personnel have worked there for decades but their work and professional performance are less than satisfactory. Nothing is done.  What is preached is not practiced.

review_title: A Dissatisfied physician with low morale

Support staff have not received a raise in years. MDs are paid in the bottom quartile for each specialty, without raises x 5 years. Major IT and scheduling issues make CNMC a very difficult place for staff and patients to navigate. Scheduling is an absolute nightmare for families, but fundraising is extremely efficient. Morale among physicians is very low and many are in the process of leaving. The nation's children's hospital, sadly, has a very long way to go.

job_title: Senior Media Relations Specialist in Washington, DC
pros:
At Children's National, you have a chance to work with doctors, clinicians, families, and staff to help children grow up stronger. It's amazing to see how far the field of pediatrics has advanced, and Children's National has dozens of subspecialized experts working at the hospital. Every project you work on advances the needs of children and the field of pediatric care, which Dr. Kurt Newman, the CEO of Children's, and a former pediatric surgeon, refers to as preventive medicine. In addition to sharing information that supports the health of children and families, or provides insight into acute critical needs, you'll get a chance to support and share a variety of innovative research taking place at the hospital and in Washington. Geneticists with the Rare Disease Institute, for example, are guiding global efforts to track genetic links (and new genes) associated with rare conditions. They also connect families, specialists, pediatricians, and other patients with each other, in an effort to share novel information to support lifelong health outcomes and advance research. 

Since this is an academic health system, you'll likely work on a variety of projects. This can range from sharing news about new research with physicians and specialists to sharing awe-inspiring stories about children with internal staff, the community, and local news outlets. As a media relations specialist, you'll also do a variety of writing for technical audiences, families, staff, and external media outlets. 

The doctors and clinicians are friendly and the children's hospital has a reputation for providing a special environment for patients. You'll see doctors dressing up as clowns, genetic counselors organizing fun and educational events for families in the cafeteria, and celebrities or athletes stop by to surprise children and their families. It's an uplifting environment. Everyone feels part of the Children's team.
cons: There aren't any cons. This is a large pediatric health system so it's helpful to know that certain processes are in place to approve content or editorial functions for public campaigns, events, or projects. If you are used to working autonomously, you'll have these benefits but you will need to allow ample time for approval for certain projects.

pros: Loved working at a children's hospital, and Children's National treats patients/families very well.
cons: Employee engagement and respect has consistently gone downhill since 2011. I sought this company out b/c it was supposed to be one of the best employers in the DC region, but was treated horribly in my last couple of years. If you're lucky, you'll work for a great manager. Just don't expect it.

review_title: Caste system in effect, morale problems
pros: If you are a medical professional, your compensation and benefits package are good and you are near the top of the corporate hierarchy.  Discounted healthcare for your children.
cons:
There is a definite caste system where non-medical, non-managerial professionals are the untouchables. Technically proficient individuals are prevented from advancing and are not considered for managerial positions as the company prefers to hire from outside. All employees are given an annual bonus, however, skilled professionals are given the same bonus, about $500, as unskilled workers. Bonuses increase substantially for managers and medical professionals.

Parking downtown is a major problem.

There are morale problems. The company has engaged a couple of consulting firms (note again the reliance on outsiders) to assess employee satisfaction over the past few years. Managers have frequent meetings, and although incentive payments have a 10% component related to communicating with staff, very little information is shared with their direct reports. When you ask for information from somebody within the department, the first question that is asked is, "Why do you need it?" People outside of the department will request the same information from many different analysts because they do not trust that they will receive accurate data.  There is currently a push to be "employer of choice," but management has not explained what it feels makes an employer an employer of choice.

The skill sets of analysts are not fully leveraged or appreciated. Claims are made that we "are paid to think," but analysts are just expected to run reports, not analyze or interpret the results.

A program has been unveiled to recognize the performance of employees on the spot, but managers are hesitant to recognize staff. The bonus is not cash, but rather points to use on goods on a dedicated web site.  One on the spot bonus is sufficient to buy a pack of socks or an old VHS tape, nothing of significance.  You need about 4 of these bonuses to buy a video game or a dress shirt.

A lot of managerial behavior is driven by incentive payments. There will not be money available to attend training or conferences because a large portion of director bonuses are based on their ability to stay under budget. Pay raises have been limited for the support staff for several years and have not kept up with the rise in the cost of living.  Although managers have not received any pay raises due to "the economy," incentive payments for the managers have continued to rise and continue to be paid out despite the state of the economy.
